attributes.magic: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2, for GNU/Linux 2.6.18, BuildID[sha1]=7b76631dd0bcc66ad0a4215b2bc5d05d779a1e4c, stripped

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects unknown Linux implants (uploads from KR and MO)
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detect the BPFDoor backdoor used by the Chinese TA Red Menshen
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Sekoia.io

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This ELF binary is a sophisticated Linux backdoor and rootkit. It exhibits several high-confidence malicious behaviors: 1) Process Masquerading: It uses prctl and strncpy to rename its process to legitimate system services like '/usr/lib/systemd/systemd-machined' and '/usr/libexec/postfix/master'. 2) Interactive Backdoor: It implements a reverse shell handler (sub_404513) that uses pseudo-terminals (/dev/ptmx), redirects standard I/O via dup2, and executes /bin/sh. 3) Anti-Forensics: It explicitly sets environment variables like HISTFILE=/dev/null and MYSQL_HISTFILE=/dev/null to prevent command logging. 4) Network Stealth: It utilizes raw sockets (AF_PACKET) for packet sniffing, likely to detect a 'magic packet' trigger. 5) Traffic Redirection: It manipulates system firewall rules via iptables (sub_403bd9) to create NAT PREROUTING redirects. 6) Persistence: It attempts to install itself into /var/lock and utilizes the daemon() function for background execution.
